39351040.review: This was a wonderful experience. It was like reading through a science fiction novel but with beautiful visuals.

39223733.review:
Acabei de zerar o jogo, não me lembro de ter jogado algum jogo tão antigo quanto este.
Jogo sensacional, imagino o impacto e surpresa que causou na época que foi lançado. Animações extremamente bem feitas e incríveis baseado no ano em que foi lançado, surpreendendo até os dias de hoje, onde ainda existem jogos de point and click do mesmo gênero, mas não vi nenhum se desenvolver tão bem quanto este. Acredito que como foi lançado numa época onde a internet não era algo comum, muitos tenham ficado presos em alguma parte, confesso que tive que ler o detonado do jogo duas vezes e fiquei preso mais de 1 hora em um puzzle (o dos ossos, se você jogou deve saber do que estou falando).
A história é ótima, o carisma dos personagens e como eles vão agindo durante o trama é muito bem trabalhado. A história é baseada em uma história do Steven Spielberg. Porém, uma coisa decepciona. Muitos podem discordar de mim, mas o final do jogo decepciona, e muito, não estando a altura do jogo. O final é muito contraditório com a história do jogo, que tem um clima mais sombrio. Se eu falar mais do que isso vou dar graves spoilers, mas fica um gosto amargo difícil de engolir ao final. Sem contar que o final "alternativo" não muda absolutamente NADA teoricamente.
Ignore os gráficos e a resolução, apenas jogue, vale muito a experiência.

Für alle Nostalgiker und Retro-Adventure-Fans ein klares Kauf-Muss!!!

38339851.review:
Hello everybody, End World Gaming here to share an excerpt from my review for The Dig by LucasArts.

The Dig is a sci-fi point and click adventure game whose concept was created by filmmaker Steven Spielberg. The game follows Boston Low, a military specialist sent on a mission with a journalist named Maggie Robins, and Archaeologist Ludger Brink, to land on an incoming asteroid to investigate where it came from and to safely destroy it.

The plan winds up failing and the three astronauts are flown to an ancient alien planet, now a wasteland/ruin. Their main mission upon arrival is survival and to find a way home. This plan has many complications throughout and through puzzle solving and exploration more of the planet’s history and the alien life that once inhabited it is revealed.

The planet is filled with beautifully drawn scenery and there are even some alien life forms scattered throughout. Even at the game’s age, the pixel art remains gorgeous to look at and it’s only enhanced by the game’s amazing soundtrack. The music is not only enjoyable to listen to but it’s also quite relaxing. It also holds up incredibly well in terms of quality, it sounds amazing throughout the game.

I will admit that the puzzles in the game were often quite challenging to figure out. They aren’t readily obvious and some of them require a lot of trial and error to figure out. The plus side to playing the game today is that there are quite a few guides out there to walk you through some of the more difficult puzzles. I also created a video walkthrough for the game which you’ll be able to watch below.

Overall, I enjoyed The Dig a great deal and I feel that if you’re as into Sci-Fi as I am, you’ll enjoy it just as much as I did. While I do admit that the graphics could be crisper and a bit more detailed, they still looked quite gorgeous given the game’s age. I also felt that the music was easily one of the best parts of the game and it really added to the overall experience. The voice acting was pretty good but I will say that it felt a bit cliched to each of the characters professions/race. I enjoyed the game though and I definitely recommend giving it a shot if you’re a fan of sci-fi like myself.

If you'd like to check out my full review or to see my final score, you can find the review here: http://www.endworldgaming.com/adventure/the-dig-review

Thanks for taking the time to check it out folks and happy gaming!

38333366.review:
This was the first adventure game that I've ever played. It came as a bonus when I've purchased my first CD + Soundblaster combo, along with some other demos from Lucas Arts. To tell you the truth, I didn't really enjoy playing it for the first time, but I guess it was because there wasn't much action involved. Either way, for some reason my mom became interested in this game, and after she advanced a little, I became more interested, that until we've got stuck. My cousin had played before, so he provided some assistance to us during our playthrough. Then some time later, my other cousin also had this PC magazine where you could find some hints to finish the game. Ok, so a lot was said, but what about the game itself?

It's one of the classic point-and-click adventures of Lucas Arts, where the game was based on a novel that was written by Alan Dean Foster (which I had the chance to read it recently, I surely recommend it to any fan of this). There's this unknown object in space, which has a risk of crashing into Earth, so this team of astronauts is sent to put a nuke inside of it and blast it into pieces. That's the basic premise that can be given, because everything that happens later can be considered spoilers.

Ok, so for an overall analysis: The story is great, it was a really nice adaptation of the novel. As for the graphics, you can't demand much, but I would really love to see a remastered version nowadays, especially because so many have been released recently. The music and sound effects are simply awesome, they definitely make you feel immersed in the environment around you. The characters are really well-built. The gameplay is quite simple, you don't need to rely on a complex menu of options to interact with stuff around you. As for the puzzles, they can drive you insane in some parts, so  there's no shame to browse any walkthrough to give you a hand.

Well, that's pretty much it. What it started as a boring game for me, eventually became one of my favourite adventure titles of all time. I hope that you've enjoyed reading this review, and if you never had the chance of playing it before, I seriously recommend you to do it.

PS. I had to install this game only to write this review... Who knows, maybe I'll just end up playing it again  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Sur GOG, vous pourrez acheter The Dig pour l'avoir en anglais, allemand, espagnol, français et italien et sous Windows, Mac et Linux.

38233440.review:
Drei Astronauten sind unerwartet in ein anderes Sternensystem entführt worden und auf einem fremdartigem Planeten gestrandet. Dieser Planet hat eine atembare Atmosphäre und scheint bis auf die Insel, auf der man landet, komplett mit Wasser bedeckt zu sein (vermutlich damit man eine überschaubare Anzahl an Locations hat; bei einem ganzen Kontinent wäre statt einem Adventure nur ein Rollenspiel in Frage gekommen).

Die Aufgabe des Spielers ist es nun, die Insel zu erkunden, mehr über die Alien-Technologie zu erfahren und einen Weg zurück zur Erde zu finden. Auf der Insel findet man zwar viele Maschinen, die von einer überragenden Technologie zeugen, aber da der Planet anscheinend unbewohnt ist, wird man neugierig, was mit den Erschaffern dieser technologischen Wunder geschehen ist. Gewürzt wird die Handlung durch die unterschiedlichen Ansichten der drei Charaktere, wodurch es mehrmals zu Streitigkeiten kommt. Unter anderem sind sie sich uneinig, ob die Menschheit für so fortgeschrittene Technologie schon bereit ist und wer die Expedition leiten soll. Man findet bei "The Dig" viele Parallelen zu "Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis", denn bei beiden Stories entdecken Archäologen phantastische Maschinen einer vergangenen Kultur, die durch einen mysteriösen Universal-Treibstoff angetrieben werden. Weiterhin sieht man bei beiden Geschichten, was diese überlegene Technologie in den Händen der falschen Leute anrichten kann.

Die Steuerung von "The Dig" ist (gegenüber anderen klassischen Adventures) sehr vereinfacht. Klickt man mit der linken Maustaste ein Objekt an, so probiert die Spielfigur, was ihr am sinnvollsten erscheint ("Nehmen", "Angucken", "Öffnen", "Benutzen"). Klickt man eine andere Stelle auf dem Bildschirm an, bewegt sich die Spielfigur in die entsprechende Richtung. Wenn man die rechte Maustaste drückt, erscheint das Inventar, in dem man Gegenstände anschauen und benutzen kann. Klickt man diese an, verändert sich der Mauscursor in den entsprechenden Gegenstand, so dass man diesen auf andere Objekte anwenden kann. Wer nun denkt, daß bei dieser einfachen Steuerung die Rätsel zu einfach sind, der irrt. LucasArts ist es gelungen, einige knackige (aber logische) Rätsel in diese einfache Steuerung einzubauen.

Die Videosequenzen sind trotz VGA-Auflösung wieder erstklassig geworden; sowohl Szenen im Zeichentrick-Stil als auch die von ILM (Industrial Light & Magic) gerenderten Kamerafahrten. Die orchestrale Musik ist eines Kinofilmes würdig, und die Sprachausgabe ist gelungen.

"The Dig" ist das ernsteste Adventure in der gesamten Firmengeschichte. Abgesehen von einigen zynischen Sprüchen hat man kaum Gelegenheit zum Schmunzeln, aber wahrscheinlich hätten ständige Kalauer die Atmosphäre dieser spannenden Science-Fiction-Geschichte zerstört.

I played this game when I was a kid and I was so fascinated about the history! I used to keep the CD all the time inside my PC because The Dig was the kind of game (with AoE) that deserved to be played all the time. Well. Several years later look what I found here! What a delighted surprise! 

Talking about the game, The Dig is a well build point and click game with and incredible and interesting story. The atmosphere is dense and you will need lots of patience and "try and error" attempts to finish all the puzzles (gosh.. that goddam turtle!). 

So, basically, The Dig is a worthy game to everyone who loves point and click story games.

37030349.review:
A mediocre adventure game that aged poorly with lackluster dialog, dispassionate voice acting, fanciful but somewhat silly setting, but worst of all: terrible puzzles.

I realize that paints a dire picture of this game. It isn't as bad as it sounds, but it isn't good either. I would grade The Dig as a solid D. But with so many other great adventure games out there, I simply can't recommend it.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
[*] Setting : Most of the game takes place on a far-away alien world. I have this as a positilve and a negative because, while it seems like the landscapes should be beautiful, the game is so low-rez and pixelated that it is difficult to really appreciate it. Needs a remastered-edition badly.
[*] Musical Score - Wonderful
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
[*] Puzzles : The single largest problem with the game are the puzzles. I love puzzles, but you need to be able to understand the rules to solve them. Alien-world puzzles tend mostly to be "try a bunch of inventory stuff with this blinky light and see if anything works." There isn't a lot of logic and reason exercised in the puzzles. And some of the puzzles are solved by, for example, saying a particular thing, to a particular character, in a particular place and time. That is: something almost entirely random that one would not try unless they had given up and wanted to simply try _everything_ (or found a walkthrough to get past being stuck). In any case: adventure games are made or broken on their puzzles, and aside from a few really great puzzles (maybe 10-20%), the rest simply aren't engaging.
[*] Visual Cues : This sort-of ties in with the puzzles, but it can be difficult to tell what objects in the game-world are supposed to be. Is that a button or just some glint on the background texture? Can I interact with that glob of unidentifiable pixel-mash? (etc) It can be difficult (and not in a good way) to try to solve problems when you can't really see what something is, or the exact shape, or if it is part of the background or interactable.
[*] Dialog : Cheesey and terrible.
[*] Voice Acting : While the voice actors have incredible voices, a lot of the time it sounds like they are simply reading off of a script
[*] Animation : Pretty bad. Characters move fairly mechanically. There are cut-sequences which might have been cutting-edge back in the day. Today I wouldn't even consider them for Saturday Morning cartoons, let alone a LucasArts title.
[*] Visuals  : Pretty bad. It seems like the world should be beautiful. They have really good notions of color-theory, and a lot of the camera shots are well-chosen. But one simply can't appreciate it when the resolution is this low.
[/list]

36481797.review: It's good! Not as fun if you know all the answers to the puzzles. Part of the joy is feeling totally lost and having to go back methodically and see what you missed earlier. 36434440.review: This game is challenging, it is insightful, and it's a tresure of it's time. I love it.

36236336.review:
Eu fui conhecer esse jogo através dos meus pais que tinham o CD e etc. Foi um dos favoritos da minha infância e até hoje continua assim, talvez seja o que me levou a gostar de visual novels e escaping games, pois ele não tem uma trama corrida e pede que o jogador tenha tanto a paciência de dialogar com os outros personagens como também precise explorar meticulosamente os mapas e cenários para prosseguir o enredo.

Por sinal, fiquei maravilhada por a versão da steam ter os dialógos dos personagens, o trabalho de atuação deixou as conversas bem mais interessantes e não ter de ficar na mesma de ler textões coloridos que enchem a metade da tela ( menção honrossa para o Brink ofendendo o alien-aranha do jeito mais polido possível ).

Meu único problema foi com a resolução do jogo (eu pelo menos não consegui alterar), e talvez algumas pessoas não gostem do quão "fechado" o jogo possa ser, tendo só dois tipos possíveis de final. Mas para quem já jogou e quer reviver a experiência, ou quer ter um gostinho de como jogos dos anos 90 eram, The Dig é  um prato cheio para essas pessoas (no mínimo 6 horas para fechar, vamos lá, pelo menos uma noite de entretenimento ele garante).

35142099.review:
Although a fan of classic point-and-click adventure games, I somehow missed [i]The Dig[/i] when it was originally released and was excited to pick it up on Steam.  I am not disappointed.

The game's beginning is almost indistinguishable from [i]Deep Impact[/i] and [i]Armaggedon[/i], but it soon takes a sharp turn towards more traditional science fiction: strange technology and alien planets.  The plot is original, and the writers did a great job with the dialogue -- the characters are believable and interesting, and their relationships develop realistically over the course of the game.

Like all games of this era, there were one or two moments that I found myself reaching for a walkthrough.  Carefully searching every pixel for interactable objects and screen pans is evidently a skill I have lost with age.
